lcInstruction.p: If you're using custom plugins, you may need to update them over time. One of the most common reasons for updating the styling of a custom plugin is a change in company branding. You may also need to update a custom plugin to accommodate changes to the source content's structure–for example, adding a new element to your specialization, or specializing for the first time.

Customizing DITA OT plugins is difficult and requires lots of testing to ensure that updates to the plugin have the desired results in the output. Because the DITA OT plugins use XSL (Extensible Markup Language), special knowledge of XSL is required to customize a default plugin or make updates to a custom plugin. For this reason, most companies hire an XSL expert–whether an outside consultant or an in-house employee–to customize plugins.

There is a more straightforward way that the xhtml plugin can be customized to update the look and feel of the content: CSS, or cascading stylesheets. The xhtml plugin includes a file called style.css, which is run through the DITA OT to give the HTML output its styling and exported along with the HTML output. Because more people have common knowledge of CSS than XSL, a company may not need to hire an XSL expert if it only produces HTML output and can rebrand its content entirely through CSS.
The following instructions will show you how to make some simple updates to the CSS for your custom xhtml plugin and generate HTML output to test the results.
